title: Does being cold make you sick?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of colds and the flu?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial infections

options.label: B
options.text: Viral infections

options.label: C
options.text: Environmental factors

options.label: D
options.text: Nutritional deficiencies

multiple-choice.question: Why do people tend to stay indoors more often during the winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too cold to go outside

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are afraid of the cold weather

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have more opportunities to interact with others

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have more time to relax

multiple-choice.question: What is one factor that can affect our immune system adversely during the winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased humidity

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased Vitamin D levels

options.label: C
options.text: Increased exposure to sunlight

options.label: D
options.text: Increased physical activity

multiple-choice.question: According to recent evidence, what happens to the blood vessels in response to cold temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: They dilate, allowing white blood cells to reach the virus more quickly

options.label: B
options.text: They constrict, slowing the white blood cells from reaching the virus

options.label: C
options.text: They remain the same, with no effect on the immune response

options.label: D
options.text: They increase in size, allowing the virus to spread more easily

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the virus's outer layer or envelope in response to cold temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes softer and more fragile

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes harder and acts like a shield

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same, with no effect on the virus's spreading ability

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears, making the virus more susceptible to the elements

title: Candy Corn In Space

multiple-choice.question: What is a surfactant molecule, according to Don Pettit?

options.label: A
options.text: A molecule that repels water

options.label: B
options.text: A molecule that attracts water

options.label: C
options.text: A molecule that is attracted to both water and oil

options.label: D
options.text: A molecule that is attracted to neither water nor oil

multiple-choice.question: In the candy corn demonstration, what represents grease or oil?

options.label: A
options.text: The candy corn

options.label: B
options.text: The water blob

options.label: C
options.text: The soap molecules

options.label: D
options.text: The surface tension

multiple-choice.question: What is the critical micelle concentration, according to Don Pettit?

options.label: A
options.text: The point at which the soap molecules start to break down

options.label: B
options.text: The point at which the soap molecules start to clean the grease

options.label: C
options.text: The point at which the soap molecules fully cover the grease blob

options.label: D
options.text: The point at which the soap molecules become water-soluble

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the blob of grease when it reaches the critical micelle concentration?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes more smushy

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes less rigid

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes water-soluble

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes invisible

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle behind how soap cleans grease, according to Don Pettit?

options.label: A
options.text: The soap molecules are attracted to the grease and repel the water

options.label: B
options.text: The soap molecules are attracted to the water and repel the grease

options.label: C
options.text: The soap molecules have a hydrophobic end that sticks into the grease and a hydrophilic end that pokes up into the water

options.label: D
options.text: The soap molecules are attracted to both the grease and the water

title: The bees that eat corpses

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the diet of vulture bees?

options.label: A
options.text: They eat only pollen and nectar from flowers.

options.label: B
options.text: They eat mostly carrion or dead things.

options.label: C
options.text: They are strictly carnivorous and only eat meat.

options.label: D
options.text: They are herbivores and only eat plants.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the hypopharyngeal gland secretions in vulture bees?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce honey for human consumption.

options.label: B
options.text: To make corpse honey for the bees' own consumption.

options.label: C
options.text: To feed the queen bee and her young.

options.label: D
options.text: To break down toxic sugars in pollen.

multiple-choice.question: What is believed to have happened in the gut microbiome of vulture bees to allow them to make a dietary 180?

options.label: A
options.text: Something unusual happened in the gut microbiome, allowing the bees to adapt to their new diet.

options.label: B
options.text: The gut microbiome remained the same as their pollen-eating ancestors.

options.label: C
options.text: The gut microbiome changed because the bees' diet changed.

options.label: D
options.text: The gut microbiome was not affected by the change in diet.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the possible explanations for the change in microbiome in vulture bees?

options.label: A
options.text: The microbes adapted to the carrion diet as the bees did.

options.label: B
options.text: The microbes were doing something unrelated to diet in the first place.

options.label: C
options.text: The change in microbiome was caused by the bees' diet change.

options.label: D
options.text: The change in microbiome was caused by the bees' environment change.

multiple-choice.question: What can the study of vulture bees' microbiome adaptation tell us?

options.label: A
options.text: How the microbiome adapts to changes in environment.

options.label: B
options.text: How the microbiome adapts to changes in diet.

options.label: C
options.text: How the microbiome adapts to changes in climate.

options.label: D
options.text: How the microbiome adapts to changes in social behavior.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Insufficient hydration

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: You start to feel thirsty

options.label: C
options.text: Your urine becomes darker

options.label: C
options.text: It can affect sleep quality

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: How An Igloo Keeps You Warm

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why snow can be used to keep warm despite being cold?

options.label: A
options.text: Because snow is made up of tiny ice crystals that trap heat.

options.label: B
options.text: Because snow is able to conduct heat away from the body.

options.label: C
options.text: Because snow is a poor conductor of heat and can help to retain body heat.

options.label: D
options.text: Because snow is a poor insulator.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the shape that a real igloo would take if sliced in half?

options.label: A
options.text: A catenary

options.label: B
options.text: A half-circle

options.label: C
options.text: A sphere

options.label: D
options.text: A rectangle

multiple-choice.question: How do Inuit hunters typically cut out igloo blocks?

options.label: A
options.text: By molding them into shape.

options.label: B
options.text: By cutting them out of solid ice.

options.label: C
options.text: By cutting them out of the ground.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a machine.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of a catenary arch in an igloo?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for more space inside the igloo.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides additional insulation.

options.label: C
options.text: It distributes weight more evenly and is more stable.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for better ventilation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why a living furnace, such as a human body, can help to warm an igloo?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the body emits heat through radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the body conducts heat away from the igloo.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the body melts the innermost layer of the walls, strengthening the barrier between the igloo and the outside air.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the body provides additional insulation.

title: Why do venomous animals live in warm climates?

multiple-choice.question: Why are the most venomous species found in the warmest places on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the heat enables the formation of venom molecules.

options.label: B
options.text: Because venomous species are more diverse in warm climates.

options.label: C
options.text: Because venomous species are more abundant in warm climates.

options.label: D
options.text: Because venomous species are more adaptable to warm climates.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why venomous snakes are more abundant in cold climates, such as Southern Australia?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cold climate allows them to survive longer.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the cold climate makes them more aggressive.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the venomous snakes radiated through Australia 20 million years ago.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the cold climate makes them more venomous.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between venomous and poisonous species?

options.label: A
options.text: Venomous species are more deadly, while poisonous species are less deadly.

options.label: B
options.text: Venomous species deliver venom through fangs, while poisonous species deliver venom through skin contact.

options.label: C
options.text: Venomous species are harmful if ingested, while poisonous species are harmful if touched.

options.label: D
options.text: Venomous species are harmful if eaten, while poisonous species are harmful if injected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of anti-venom?

options.label: A
options.text: To kill the venomous species.

options.label: B
options.text: To neutralize the venom in the body.

options.label: C
options.text: To stimulate the production of antibodies.

options.label: D
options.text: To treat the symptoms of venom poisoning.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to explain the distribution of venomous species on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is no clear pattern.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the distribution is influenced by many factors, including evolutionary history and ecology.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the distribution is random.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the distribution is not well-studied.

title: Are we all related?

options.label: B
options.text: Because our ancestors had many children.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our family trees have many forks.

options.label: D
options.text: The island's environmental degradation

options.label: A
options.text: The opportunity to rebuild his home

options.label: B
options.text: The chance to leave the island

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that his home is still standing

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How does herd immunity work?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of vaccines, according to the video?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect individuals from getting sick.

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the entire population from getting sick.

options.label: C
options.text: To cure diseases.

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the spread of diseases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept called that explains how vaccines can protect the entire population, even if not everyone gets vaccinated?

options.label: A
options.text: Herd immunity.

options.label: B
options.text: Herd threshold.

options.label: C
options.text: Vaccine efficacy.

options.label: D
options.text: Disease prevention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the R0 (reproduction number) for the virus that causes COVID-19?

options.label: D
options.text: Scientists are still trying to figure out for certain.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of people need to be immune to a disease to reach herd immunity, according to the video?

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of vaccines, according to the video?

options.label: A
options.text: They only protect the individual who gets vaccinated.

options.label: B
options.text: They only protect the community where the vaccine is given.

options.label: C
options.text: They can protect more than one person.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only effective for certain diseases.

title: How short selling works

multiple-choice.question: What is the opposite approach to a traditional long position in investing?

options.label: A
options.text: Buying a security today and selling it at a later date.

options.label: B
options.text: Selling a security today and buying it back in the future.

options.label: C
options.text: Buying a security at a low price and selling it at a high price.

options.label: D
options.text: Selling a security at a high price and buying it back at a low price.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of an initial margin in a short position?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the potential return on investment.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the risk of a loss.

options.label: C
options.text: To act as a buffer in case the investment loses value.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a guarantee of a profit.

multiple-choice.question: What is a short squeeze?

options.label: A
options.text: A situation where a heavily shorted stock sees its price surge due to investors buying back the stock.

options.label: B
options.text: A situation where a heavily longed stock sees its price surge due to investors selling the stock.

options.label: C
options.text: A situation where a stock's price falls due to a lack of demand.

options.label: D
options.text: A situation where a stock's price rises due to an increase in supply.

multiple-choice.question: What is the biggest risk with short positions?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of a short squeeze.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of a buy-in.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of a skewed payoff.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of a loss of principal.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the risk-reward profile of a long position and a short position?

options.label: A
options.text: A long position has a higher potential return but a lower risk, while a short position has a lower potential return but a higher risk.

options.label: B
options.text: A long position has a lower potential return but a higher risk, while a short position has a higher potential return but a lower risk.

options.label: C
options.text: A long position has a higher potential return and a higher risk, while a short position has a lower potential return and a lower risk.

options.label: D
options.text: A long position has a lower potential return and a lower risk, while a short position has a higher potential return and a higher risk.

title: Why the ancient Greeks couldn't see blue

multiple-choice.question: Why didn't the ancient Greeks mention the color blue in their writings, such as in Homer's "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey"?

options.label: A
options.text: They were all color blind.

options.label: B
options.text: They saw colors differently than we do.

options.label: C
options.text: They didn't have a word for blue.

options.label: D
options.text: Blue was not a significant color in their culture.

multiple-choice.question: What is the order in which colors enter language in every single culture, according to researchers?

options.label: A
options.text: Black, white, red, green, yellow, blue

options.label: B
options.text: Black, white, red, yellow, green, blue

options.label: C
options.text: Black, white, red, green, yellow, blue

options.label: D
options.text: Black, white, red, yellow, blue, green

multiple-choice.question: Why is blue often the last color to enter language in every culture, according to researchers?

options.label: A
options.text: Because blue is a rare color in nature.

options.label: B
options.text: Because blue is a hard color to create.

options.label: C
options.text: Because blue is not as important as other colors.

options.label: D
options.text: Because blue is not as noticeable as other colors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Himba people's perception of colors, and how does it differ from ours?

options.label: A
options.text: The Himba people see colors more clearly than we do, but they have fewer words for colors.

options.label: B
options.text: The Himba people see colors less clearly than we do, but they have more words for colors.

options.label: C
options.text: The Himba people see colors in the same way as we do, but they have different words for colors.

options.label: D
options.text: The Himba people see colors differently than we do, and they have fewer words for colors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of language on our perception of colors, according to neuroscience?

options.label: A
options.text: Language has no impact on our perception of colors.

options.label: B
options.text: Language helps us to see colors more clearly.

options.label: C
options.text: Language trains our brain to see colors differently.

options.label: D
options.text: Language makes us see colors in the same way as we do without it.

title: Why do we get goose bumps?

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific term for the experience of having goosebumps?

options.label: A
options.text: Pilomotor reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Euphoric response

options.label: C
options.text: Fight or flight response

options.label: D
options.text: Thermoregulation

options.label: A
options.text: To contract and relax the hair follicle

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: To stimulate the sympathetic nervous system

options.label: D
options.text: To produce dopamine release

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because sad songs are more complex in structure

options.label: D
options.text: Because sad songs are more relaxing

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What would happen if the world went vegetarian?

multiple-choice.question: If everyone in the world suddenly became a vegetarian, what would happen to the domestic animals currently raised for food?

options.label: A
options.text: They would continue to be raised in large numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: They would be used for other purposes, such as companionship or labor.

options.label: C
options.text: They would disappear, freeing up vast quantities of land.

options.label: D
options.text: They would be used for food in other parts of the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main effects of livestock production on the climate?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: C
options.text: It is responsible for about 15% of global greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: D
options.text: It is responsible for more than all the world's planes, trains, and automobiles put together.

multiple-choice.question: How much water is used to produce a kilogram of beef?
What would be a consequence of a sudden increase in vegetarianism, particularly in developing countries?

options.label: A
options.text: Many small-scale farmers would be able to switch to producing milk or eggs.

options.label: B
options.text: Many small-scale farmers would be faced with their way of life becoming obsolete.

options.label: C
options.text: The global economy would benefit from the increased demand for vegetable crops.

options.label: D
options.text: The world would experience a shortage of vegetable-based alternatives.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the trends observed in countries like India and China?

options.label: A
options.text: A decline in meat consumption as people become wealthier.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in meat consumption as people become wealthier.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in the number of people raising and processing animals.

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in the number of people becoming vegetarians.

title: How to process your emotions

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why do we often fail to process our emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we are too busy with our daily activities.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it hurts a lot to acknowledge and understand our emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we are not aware of the existence of our emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are not interested in emotional processing.

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in anxiety and depression.

options.label: B
options.text: A feeling of numbness and disconnection.

options.label: C
options.text: An alleviation in our general mood.

options.label: D
options.text: A complete elimination of negative emotions.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Good friends, two deft therapists, and ritual moments like philosophical meditation.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Insomnia.

options.label: B
options.text: Depression.

options.label: C
options.text: Anxiety.

options.label: D
options.text: Physical illness.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we often avoid processing our emotions, according to the transcript?
